document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the willow catkin flies, genus Egle Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Anthomyiidae), in Europe and neighbouring areas

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the willow catkin flies, genus Egle Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Anthomyiidae), in Europe and neighbouring areas

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
‘
Egle minuta (Meigen)
’;
Lyneborg 1965: 220
(in part), figs. 26–28. Misidentification.

‘
Egle podulparia Suh
& Kwon’;
Ólafsson 1991: 55
;
Petersen 2001: 184
(in part). Misidentification.

Egle lyneborgi Ackland & Griffiths
in
Griffiths, 2003: 2357
, figs. 2674–2683; Ackland 2003: 84; Michelsen 2004 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Very similar to
Egle minuta
but different as follows:

Male. Terminalia ( Figs. 164–169 ): Sternite V with 0–1 setula postero-laterally on basal plate. Epandrium smaller, without setulae on lateral parts (as in
E. parva
and
E. suwai
). Surstyli narrow-based alongside margins of cerci (as in
E. parva
and
E. suwai
); surstyli in lateral view broader on distal half. Apical extension of cerci not constricted on basal part, usually slightly tapering on distal third. Pregonite wider than long; postgonite without anterior transverse edge. Phallus with smaller and distally less inflated epiphallus.
Female. Oviscapt ( Fig. 198 ): Sternite VII slightly broader and sclerotized on middle part; hypoproct more reduced, only consisting of minor apical part with a pair of setulae.

Biology. In Iceland reared from catkins of Tea-leafed willow (
Salix phylicifolia
L.) ( Lyneborg 1965 ). Adults of both sexes have been collected in south Sweden on male catkins of Creeping willow (
S. repens
L.), while Danish specimens have been taken on flowering Goat willow (
S. caprea
L.) and Grey willow (
S. cinerea
L.).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. A Holarctic species, but Palaearctic distribution poorly documented due to confusion with other species until quite recently. Recorded from Iceland , British Isles, Italy and Sweden ( Griffiths 2003 ), and from Denmark and Norway ( Michelsen 2004 ). Presently recorded for the first time from Finland and Spain . Widespread in boreal and western parts of North America according to Griffiths (2003) .

Relationships.
Egle lyneborgi
belongs to the
E. minuta
species group within the
E. minuta
section (see above).
